title: Metro Bank boss Vernon Hill steps down as chairman with immediate effect
text:
Metro Bank's founder Vernon Hill is stepping down from his role as chairman of the bank 'with immediate effect.'

In July, the bank said Hill would be stepping down as chairman and stay on as the company's president and non executive director.

Earlier this month, Metro Bank said Hill would be quitting the group by the end of the year.

Hill will stay on at the group as a non-executive director until 31 December and has agreed to accept an honorary position as 'emeritus chairman.'

Stepping down: Metro Bank's founder Vernon Hill is stepping down from his role as chairman of the bank 'with immediate effect'

Hill said: 'I wish all of our fans - Metro Bank's customers, colleagues and shareholders - every success for the next stage of the journey. As always, the best is yet to come.'

According to the Telegraph, the bank is debating whether to continue funding Hill's £120,000-a-year expense allowance next year.

The controversial American billionaire will be replaced on an interim basis by Sir Michael Snyder, who joined Metro's board in 2015 and was the City of London's policy chairman from 2002 to 2008.

Sir Michael Snyder, said: 'The Board thanks Vernon for his vision which inspired and created Metro Bank ten years ago.

'He leaves a lasting legacy of creating fans through exceptional customer service and has revolutionised British banking.'

The challenger bank will publish its third-quarter results later today.

Slumping shares: Metro Bank's shares have been decimated since the start of this year

Metro Bank's shares have been decimated since the start of this year after it revealed a £900million accounting blunder in January.

Hill's departure comes after months of pressure from investors and regulators who expressed unease about his decision to remain on the company board despite resigning as chairman.

The bank's troubles were compounded when it was forced to abandon a bond offer, initially planned to secure £250million.

The group relaunched fundraising plans earlier this month, looking to raise £300million, which soared to around £475million on strong demand from investors.

Hill co-founded the bank more than eight years ago, focusing on building customer-friendly branches.

But, the business has faced questions over the viability of its high street-led model in a banking industry increasingly moving to digital.

Shares in Metro Bank are up 0.46 per cent or 0.89p to 193.89.
